Author: Goladus
Content:
Favorites are Mozart, Brahms, Bach, Chopin, and Beethoven but like dfranke 'omnivorous classical' is a pretty good description. But I will pretty much listen to anything.

Some of my favorite performers are John Eliot Gardiner, Andre Previn, the Kronos Quartet, Cecelia Bartoli, Murray Perahia, Mitsuko Uchida, Emmanuel Ax, Alison Hagley, Bryn Terfel, and Yo Yo Ma.

And I also often prefer quiet when hacking, and only listen to music to drown out distractions.

Author: karzeem
Content:
A couple of the questions were surprisingly easy (e.g. find the area of a circle, given its radius), but you're right about most of it.

Interesting how on the English section, the questions were basically trivia. There wasn't much at all in that part testing skills, as opposed to specific knowledge.

Author: dfranke
Content: I can't listen to Baroque music while coding.  The same brain cells that I'm trying to use for coding get tied up with unweaving the strands of melody.

Author: dfranke
Content: Omnivorous classical, but particularly the Renaissance and Baroque periods.  My favorite composers are Bach, Dufay, Ockeghem, Morley, Byrd, Mussorgsky, and Respighi.  Ensemble Unicorn is my favorite group of performers.

Author: mnemonicsloth
Content:
I think this is software-centric thinking.

If you look at hardware, you really need a Ph.D. to make a serious contribution to theory, and a lot of important founders (Intel springs to mind) had doctorates.\n

Author: menloparkbum
Content: While programming, I prefer either baroque classical music or weird glitchy sounding electronic music. When I'm not programming, anything goes.

Author: mechanical_fish
Content:
I used to live less than a few hundred feet from the Hayward Fault in Fremont. Then I solved my earthquake problem by moving to Boston.

However, I was listening to a podcast of Mark and Mary Lou Zoback (the cheerful geologists of doom) giving a lecture at Stanford, and I was suddenly reminded that I know a lot of friends, colleagues, and websites that still live in the Bay Area, and it would be a terrible shame to lose any of them to collapsing bookshelves, cheap apartments, lack of fresh water, or week-long communication outages.

(You can find the podcasted lecture on the Stanford section of the iTunes store for free, if you search hard enough; a writeup of it is here: http://daily.stanford.edu/article/2006/4/17/quakeCentennialT... )

Author: nailer
Content:
You could also run a VNC server, which provides the same abilities (an X display that runs on a machine, that you can disconnect from and reconnect to later if you wish).

For people who just need to do that the topic says (rather than run apps somewhere they can't see like you need to), here's a simpler solution:

In Linux:

ssh -X user@host:appname

If you want a full X display server, run:

ssh -X user@host:Xnest

If using Windows, get Xming (a Windows X display server) first, and turn on X forwarding in Putty or your other SSH client. \n
